subject: Re: [junit] suppressing test cases from base class in an extended	class
msgSnippet: Or better yet, create a delegated class (Helper) that will do the setUp and tearDown work, cut out the inheritance and have both test cases delegate to the
messageBody:
Or better yet, create a delegated class (Helper) that will do the setUp
and tearDown work, cut out the inheritance and have both test cases
delegate to the Helper for their setUp and tearDown. This is called
(duh!) the Delegator pattern. It's clean, simple, easy to test (yes,
you can test even your fixtures :) and it doesn't garble the code with a
bunch of unneeded inheritance.

=jason

On Tue, 2003-02-25 at 14:38, J. B. Rainsberger wrote: So said Alok
Daipuria on 2003-02-25 --------------------

>I have an existing test case class which I extended to add few more
test
>cases. When I run the extended test case, it runs the test cases from
the
>base class as well. Is there a flag or something which I can use to
>suppress
>running test cases present in the base class.
> Here's an example of the scenario :
>
> class A extends TestCase
> {
> public testA() {}
> }
>
> class B extends A
> {
> public testB() {}
> }
>
> When I execute class B, it runs both testA() and testB(), which I
want to
>avoid for now. I need to extend to be able to use the setup/teardown
done
>by
>A.

The solution is straight Java inheritance, and not JUnit-related. Pull
out the code from A that you want B to use, then create a common
superclass.

Good luck.
